title: Zara shopper jailed and handed lifetime ban for tricking retailer's returns policy
text:

A Zara customer has been sentenced to six months in prison for taking the tags off new clothes and putting them on older items of clothing to return to store.

The woman, named in reports as Tania M.A., 31, came up with a plan to wear Zara clothing for free in the city of Zaragoza in north-east Spain.

She would buy clothes in Zara shops around the city, take the tags off, and then put them on older items that she had already worn, before returning the goods back to the store.

The serial returner would then ask for a full refund - using excuses such as the item didn't fit, to get her money back.

(Image: Reuters)

The customer is said to have worked "meticulously" on the tags, even knowing which bar codes corresponded to which shades of clothing.

She would never ask for the refunds in cash as she knew this would require a boss to authorise it, and, according to the judge, she knew the bosses' "greater knowledge of the stock would allow them to detect that the returned clothing did not correspond to the tags".

However, local media reports claim she repeated the scam so many times in 15 months that staff became suspicious and reported her for fraud.

She was charged with "continual fraud", found guilty and handed a six-month prison sentence along with a lifetime ban from Zara shops in the Aragon region.

(Image: Getty)

"The fact that both the interior and exterior tags matched and were precisely placed on clothing of similar colour shows the fraudulent mechanism and desire to benefit, so in that way, she renewed her wardrobe at no cost," the judge said.

Inditex, the multinational company which owns Zara, reportedly showed six fraudulent operations between October 2017 and March 2018.

The company - which recoded sales of £772.5million in the first half of 2019 - is not the only retailer cracking down on serial returners.

One in five retailers say they have taken measures to toughen up their returns policies this year, with a further 19% planning to do so in the next 12 months .

Barclaycard said four in 10 businesses have done so to clamp down on customers who knowingly over-order, while three in 10 claim shoppers are using items and then returning them.

And consumers are feeling the impact. More than 14% said they have been penalised by a retailer for their returns behaviour, from warning emails to account deactivations.

(Image: PA)

Back in April, fashion retailer Asos announced it had changed its refunds policy to block such offenders .

In a list of sweeping changes, the clothing behemoth said it had extended its returns period - up from 28 days to 45 to allow customers to try on clothes and decide if they wish to keep them.

But alongside the changes, it added that a crackdown on fraud is underway - meaning customers who regularly buy items to wear once then return - might now be considered suspicious and refused a refund.

In an email sent out to customers, the brand said: "We know easy returns are one of the (many) reasons you shop with us, so we've increased the time you can return stuff from 28 days to 45 days.

"If you return anything within 28 days, we’ll refund you as normal… and after that (up to 45 days), you’ll now get an Asos gift voucher for the amount you spent.

"We also need to make sure our returns remain sustainable for us and for the environment, so if we notice an unusual pattern, we might investigate and take action. It’s unlikely to affect you, but we wanted to give you a heads up.

"If we notice an unusual pattern of returns activity that doesn't sit right: e.g. we suspect someone is actually wearing their purchases and then returning them or ordering and returning loads – way, waaay more than even the most loyal Asos customer would order – then we might have to deactivate the account and any associated accounts."

And if you're caught, you could have your access or account blocked.
description: The woman would routinely buy clothes, take the tags off, and then put them on older, used items, which she'd then return
